elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">(a) Coordination environment of [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] cores and L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>. Ball-and-stick (b) and topology (c) representations of the two-interpenetrated diamondoid network (b and c) of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Both [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] and L1 in (b) and (c) are represented as 4-connected nodes. The H atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) Coordination environment of [Zn4(PDC)4] cores and L1. Ball-and-stick (b) and topology (c) representations of the two-interpenetrated diamondoid network (b and c) of complex 1. Both [Zn4(PDC)4] and L1 in (b) and (c) are represented as 4-connected nodes. The H atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0010">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">(a) Coordination environment of Zn atom and L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. Ball-and-stick (b) and topology (c) representations of 2D sheet built from L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and Zn atom of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in (b) and (c) are represented as 3-connected nodes. The H atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  (a) Coordination environment of Zn atom and L2. Ball-and-stick (b) and topology (c) representations of 2D sheet built from L2 and Zn atom of complex 2. L2 in (b) and (c) are represented as 3-connected nodes. The H atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity.

elements.content:

<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">PXRD patterns for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: (a) simulated (red), (b) as-synthesized (black). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  PXRD patterns for 1 and 2: (a) simulated (red), (b) as-synthesized (black). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

<ce:section-title>Highlight</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">► Two coordination polymers have been isolated under hydrothermal conditions. ► Differently oriented N-atoms in the tetrahedral isomers play a significant role in assembly of their final topologies and luminescence-tuning. ► The structural diversity is attributed to both positional isomeric effect of tetrahedral linkers and the steric hindrance of PDC used in the self-assembly process.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlight

► Two coordination polymers have been isolated under hydrothermal conditions. ► Differently oriented N-atoms in the tetrahedral isomers play a significant role in assembly of their final topologies and luminescence-tuning. ► The structural diversity is attributed to both positional isomeric effect of tetrahedral linkers and the steric hindrance of PDC used in the self-assembly process.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">To systematically investigate the influence of the positional isomeric effect on the structures of their complexes, we prepared two Zn(II) complexes [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>)(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O based on a couple of tetrahedral linkers (L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>tetrakis(4-pyridyloxymethylene)methane; L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>tetrakis(3-pyridyloxymethylene)methane) in the presence of the carboxylate linkers (PDC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid). Their structures and properties can be tuned by variable N-donor positions of the tetrahedral isomers. The X-ray crystallographic analysis demonstrate three-dimensional ones of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and two-dimensional ones of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. This work indicates that isomeric effect of the couple of isomers play an important role in the construction of the Zn(II) complexes. In addition, their thermostability and photoluminescence are also reported in detail.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

To systematically investigate the influence of the positional isomeric effect on the structures of their complexes, we prepared two Zn(II) complexes [Zn4(L1)(PDC)4]⋅5H2O and [Zn2(L2)2(PDC)2]⋅3H2O based on a couple of tetrahedral linkers (L1 =tetrakis(4-pyridyloxymethylene)methane; L2 =tetrakis(3-pyridyloxymethylene)methane) in the presence of the carboxylate linkers (PDC=pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid). Their structures and properties can be tuned by variable N-donor positions of the tetrahedral isomers. The X-ray crystallographic analysis demonstrate three-dimensional ones of complex 1 and two-dimensional ones of complex 2. This work indicates that isomeric effect of the couple of isomers play an important role in the construction of the Zn(II) complexes. In addition, their thermostability and photoluminescence are also reported in detail.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The synthesis of Porous Metal–Organic Frameworks (PMOFs) has gained much attention in recent years because of a variety of regulated and interesting structural topologies and many-potential applications . The successful preparation of porous materials is mainly dependent on the self assembly of metal ions and multi-dentate linkers with specific coordination geometry. The self-assembly process has been affected by many factors, involving coordination modes, the nature of linkers and reaction conditions . In fact, the key to synthesize these porous materials is the careful design of organic linkers. The nature of organic linkers can directly affect the structure diversity and properties of these materials due to the difference in the size, the flexibility, positions of functional groups and coordination modes to various metal ions . To date, extensive research efforts have been focused on the preparation of new organic linkers and their use in the assembly of new coordination polymers. However, the combination study on positional isomeric effect of organic linkers and the diversity of structure in these solids is of great importance in understanding the relationship between their structure and intrinsic properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The synthesis of Porous Metal-Organic Frameworks (PMOFs) has gained much attention in recent years because of a variety of regulated and interesting structural topologies and many-potential applications . The successful preparation of porous materials is mainly dependent on the self assembly of metal ions and multi-dentate linkers with specific coordination geometry. The self-assembly process has been affected by many factors, involving coordination modes, the nature of linkers and reaction conditions . In fact, the key to synthesize these porous materials is the careful design of organic linkers. The nature of organic linkers can directly affect the structure diversity and properties of these materials due to the difference in the size, the flexibility, positions of functional groups and coordination modes to various metal ions . To date, extensive research efforts have been focused on the preparation of new organic linkers and their use in the assembly of new coordination polymers. However, the combination study on positional isomeric effect of organic linkers and the diversity of structure in these solids is of great importance in understanding the relationship between their structure and intrinsic properties.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">To evaluate the influence of positional isomeric effect on the formation of the coordination frameworks, we have introduced a couple of tetrahedral linkers as the tectons in this work. Among the N-donor tetrahedral linkers, tetrakis(4-pyridyloxymethylene) methane (L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>), is a good candidate for the construction of MOFs, due to their specific configurations and flexible conformers . In view of the structural similarity to L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>, we select another N-donor positional isomers and tetrahedral linker tetrakis(3-pyridyloxymethylene) methane (L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>). However, MOFs based on tetrahedral linker L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> remain largely unexplored so far. Here in, A couple of complexes based on metal ions, L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> or L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and PDC have synthesized under hydrothermal conditions: [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>)(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1) and [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (2). These complexes are characterized by X-ray crystallography, elemental analysis, infrared spectra (IR), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermogravimetric (TG) analyses. In addition, their photoluminescence and positional isomeric effect of the tetrahedral linker for the metal complexes have been discussed .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To evaluate the influence of positional isomeric effect on the formation of the coordination frameworks, we have introduced a couple of tetrahedral linkers as the tectons in this work. Among the N-donor tetrahedral linkers, tetrakis(4-pyridyloxymethylene) methane (L1), is a good candidate for the construction of MOFs, due to their specific configurations and flexible conformers . In view of the structural similarity to L1, we select another N-donor positional isomers and tetrahedral linker tetrakis(3-pyridyloxymethylene) methane (L2). However, MOFs based on tetrahedral linker L2 remain largely unexplored so far. Here in, A couple of complexes based on metal ions, L1 or L2 and PDC have synthesized under hydrothermal conditions: [Zn4(L1)(PDC)4]⋅5H2O (1) and [Zn2(L1)2(PDC)2]⋅3H2O (2). These complexes are characterized by X-ray crystallography, elemental analysis, infrared spectra (IR), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermogravimetric (TG) analyses. In addition, their photoluminescence and positional isomeric effect of the tetrahedral linker for the metal complexes have been discussed .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>General methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> and L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> were prepared according to the literature method . All other chemicals were from commercial source without further purification. Elemental analyses of C, H, N were determined with a Perkin–Elmer 2400C elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded in the range of 400–4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> on a Vector 22 Bruker spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets. Thermal analysis (TG) was carried out in a nitrogen stream using Seiko Extar 6000 TG/DTA equipment with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns were measured using a Rigaku D/max-RA diffractometer with Cu<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Kα radiation. Photoluminescence analyses were performed on a Hitachi 850 fluorescence spectrophotometer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General methods

L1 and L2 were prepared according to the literature method . All other chemicals were from commercial source without further purification. Elemental analyses of C, H, N were determined with a Perkin-Elmer 2400C elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded in the range of 400-4000cm-1 on a Vector 22 Bruker spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets. Thermal analysis (TG) was carried out in a nitrogen stream using Seiko Extar 6000 TG/DTA equipment with a heating rate of 10°C/min. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns were measured using a Rigaku D/max-RA diffractometer with CuKα radiation. Photoluminescence analyses were performed on a Hitachi 850 fluorescence spectrophotometer.

synthesis

Synthesis of the complex 1 

Colorless crystals of 1 were grown from solvothermal reactions of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.3448g, 0.2mmol), L1 (0.0444g, 0.1mmol) and PDC (0.0167g, 0.1mmol) in the mixed solvents of DMF and H2O (v/v=3:3) in a 25mL acid-digestion bomb at 90°C for 3d. The product was washed with water and dried under vacuum. Complex 1 was isolated as a single-phase product (yield: 45.3% based on L1). Anal. Calc. for C53H54N8O25Zn4: C 43.5, H 3.7, N 7.7. Found: C 43.4, H 3.5, N 7.8. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3436.44s, 1414.27s, 1511.31s, 1442.32s, 1365.08s, 1302.85s, 1212.80s, 1062.56s, 1032.92s, 916.60s, 853.05w, 769.16w, 737.90w, 691.71w, 538.54w.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>X-ray crystallographic determinations for the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The single-crystal X-ray data collection for the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were performed on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Kα radiation (<ce:italic>k</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at room temperature. Data reductions and absorption corrections were performed using the SAINT and SADABS software packages, respectively. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full matrix least-squares methods on F2 using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs , using atomic scattering factors for neutral atoms. Anisotropic displacement parameters were refined for all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms of the coordination water molecules and linkers were included in the structure factor calculation at idealized positions by using a riding model and refined isotropically. Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps and All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of the linkers were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically. The relevant crystallographic data are presented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor> and selected bond lengths and angles are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0015"></ce:float-anchor>. These data at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre and allocated the deposition numbers CCDC 883778 and 883779 can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallographic determinations for the complex 1 and 2 

The single-crystal X-ray data collection for the complex 1 and 2 were performed on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (k =0.71073Å) at room temperature. Data reductions and absorption corrections were performed using the SAINT and SADABS software packages, respectively. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full matrix least-squares methods on F2 using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs , using atomic scattering factors for neutral atoms. Anisotropic displacement parameters were refined for all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms of the coordination water molecules and linkers were included in the structure factor calculation at idealized positions by using a riding model and refined isotropically. Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps and All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of the linkers were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically. The relevant crystallographic data are presented in   and selected bond lengths and angles are given in   . These data at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre and allocated the deposition numbers CCDC 883778 and 883779 can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Descriptions of crystal structures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction shows that the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the tetragonal space group I4(1)/<ce:italic>a</ce:italic> and the asymmetric unit consists of one Zn(II) ion, one forth of L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>, one PDC and five water molecules. Each Zn atom is six-coordinated in a highly distorted octahedral geometry by four oxygen atoms from two distinct PDC, two nitrogen atoms from one L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> and one PDC, The bond lengths are 2.130(2)–2.2393(19)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for Zn–O, 2.009(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for Zn–N, respectively, and the corresponding bond angles around the Zn atom are in the range of 97.94(9)–152.84(8)°. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a, the secondary building unit (SBU) of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains a distorted tetrahedral [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] core, in which four Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> atoms are linked by O-donors from carboxylate groups of PDC with a Zn⋯Zn distance of. 5.055<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Each tetrahedral linker L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> with the quaternary carbon atom coordinates via its N donor atoms to four [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] cores, resulting in the formation of a 3D framework (b). Better insight into the framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be achieved by topology analysis. The tetrahedral linker L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> and [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] core are both viewed as 4-connected nodes, and then the whole networks of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be reduced into a 2-fold interpenetrated sphalerite (ZnS) structure (c). In addition, according to Cheetham’s classification, the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> falls in 3-D network with M–L–M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0 and inorganic connectivity<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3 (I<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>O<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>) . Two identical 3-D frameworks interpenetrate each other to fill part of free space in 1, leaving relatively large space for the inclusion of water guest molecules. Calculations using PLATON based on the crystal structure show that the total solvent-accessible volume comprises 40.6% of the crystal volume. Steric hindrance effect of pyridine groups in [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] cores could prevent interpenetration, which are more than that of halide groups in Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>X<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> clusters .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Descriptions of crystal structures

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction shows that the complex 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal space group I4(1)/a and the asymmetric unit consists of one Zn(II) ion, one forth of L1, one PDC and five water molecules. Each Zn atom is six-coordinated in a highly distorted octahedral geometry by four oxygen atoms from two distinct PDC, two nitrogen atoms from one L1 and one PDC, The bond lengths are 2.130(2)-2.2393(19)Å for Zn-O, 2.009(2)Å for Zn-N, respectively, and the corresponding bond angles around the Zn atom are in the range of 97.94(9)-152.84(8)°. As shown in  a, the secondary building unit (SBU) of 1 contains a distorted tetrahedral [Zn4(PDC)4] core, in which four ZnII atoms are linked by O-donors from carboxylate groups of PDC with a Zn⋯Zn distance of. 5.055Å. Each tetrahedral linker L1 with the quaternary carbon atom coordinates via its N donor atoms to four [Zn4(PDC)4] cores, resulting in the formation of a 3D framework (b). Better insight into the framework of 1 can be achieved by topology analysis. The tetrahedral linker L1 and [Zn4(PDC)4] core are both viewed as 4-connected nodes, and then the whole networks of 1 can be reduced into a 2-fold interpenetrated sphalerite (ZnS) structure (c). In addition, according to Cheetham's classification, the structure of 1 falls in 3-D network with M-L-M=0 and inorganic connectivity=3 (I3O0) . Two identical 3-D frameworks interpenetrate each other to fill part of free space in 1, leaving relatively large space for the inclusion of water guest molecules. Calculations using PLATON based on the crystal structure show that the total solvent-accessible volume comprises 40.6% of the crystal volume. Steric hindrance effect of pyridine groups in [Zn4(PDC)4] cores could prevent interpenetration, which are more than that of halide groups in Cu4X4 clusters .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2(1)/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>. In the asymmetry unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, there are one Zn atom, one chelating ligand PDC, one L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> ligand and three water guest molecules. Each Zn ion is in a highly distorted octahedral geometry, coordinated by two O–donors from one PDC, four N-donors from three L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and one PDC. The Zn–O bond distances vary in the range of 2.159(2)−2.197(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Zn–N bond distances vary in the range of 2.028(3)–2.224(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which are all similar to those found in other Zn(II) compounds  and the corresponding bond angles around the Zn atom are in the range of 75.96(12)–175.78(12)°. Two Zn(II) ions are bridged by the two N-donors from each L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> linker, forming a four-membered [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] ring, whose internal dimensions is 10.005<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.837<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a). Each Zn(II) ions [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] ring is linked by one of the other two N-donors of each L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> linker to generate a two-dimensional (2D) layer structure. Meanwhile, each layer interacts with neighboring layers via hydrogen-bond between the water guest molecules and PDC, further extending the 2D layers into a 3D supramolecular framework (b). To further understand the structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, a topological analysis of the network has been performed using Topos by considering both the metal and L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> as topological nodes. Each tetrahedral linker L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is 3-connected, and then each Zn ion becomes a 2-connected node. Therefore <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be reduced into a (2,3)-connected net with 4.8(2) (c). According to Cheetham’s classification, the structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> also belong to 3-D network with M–L–M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0 and inorganic connectivity<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3 (I<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>O<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2(1)/n. In the asymmetry unit of 2, there are one Zn atom, one chelating ligand PDC, one L2 ligand and three water guest molecules. Each Zn ion is in a highly distorted octahedral geometry, coordinated by two O-donors from one PDC, four N-donors from three L2 and one PDC. The Zn-O bond distances vary in the range of 2.159(2)-2.197(3)Å, and the Zn-N bond distances vary in the range of 2.028(3)-2.224(3)Å, which are all similar to those found in other Zn(II) compounds  and the corresponding bond angles around the Zn atom are in the range of 75.96(12)-175.78(12)°. Two Zn(II) ions are bridged by the two N-donors from each L2 linker, forming a four-membered [Zn2(L)2] ring, whose internal dimensions is 10.005×9.837Å2 ( a). Each Zn(II) ions [Zn2(L)2] ring is linked by one of the other two N-donors of each L2 linker to generate a two-dimensional (2D) layer structure. Meanwhile, each layer interacts with neighboring layers via hydrogen-bond between the water guest molecules and PDC, further extending the 2D layers into a 3D supramolecular framework (b). To further understand the structure of 2, a topological analysis of the network has been performed using Topos by considering both the metal and L2 as topological nodes. Each tetrahedral linker L2 is 3-connected, and then each Zn ion becomes a 2-connected node. Therefore 2 can be reduced into a (2,3)-connected net with 4.8(2) (c). According to Cheetham's classification, the structure of 2 also belong to 3-D network with M-L-M=0 and inorganic connectivity=3 (I3O0) .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Positional isomeric effect of L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> and L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> on structural diversity</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, each L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> ligand adopts the monodentate coordination mode and its four nitrogen atoms ligand all take part in coordination to four distinct zinc atoms, while, in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, Each L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> ligand with four pyridine N-donors leave one pyridine exposed. The phenomenon of structural diversification in L <ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>and L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> may mainly attribute to positional isomeric effect: (1) The couple of tetrahedral linkers<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>exhibit different positions of the N-donor, in which the pyridine groups can adopt exposure and bridging modes, respectively. (2) the differently oriented N-donor in these isomers will result in different topological structures. In fact, the differently oriented N-donor in these isomers can be attributed to good conformation freedom, which is similar to those built from flexible aliphatic dicarboxylates . In addition, it is obvious that the presence of PDC encourages great variety of resulting complexes. Pyridine groups in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> may have different steric hindrance, which can have effect on the coordination modes of carboxylate groups. In fact, the structural diversity is attributed to both positional isomeric effect of tetrahedral linkers and the steric hindrance of PDC used in the self-assembly process.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Positional isomeric effect of L1 and L2 on structural diversity

In 1, each L1 ligand adopts the monodentate coordination mode and its four nitrogen atoms ligand all take part in coordination to four distinct zinc atoms, while, in 2, Each L2 ligand with four pyridine N-donors leave one pyridine exposed. The phenomenon of structural diversification in L 1and L2 may mainly attribute to positional isomeric effect: (1) The couple of tetrahedral linkersexhibit different positions of the N-donor, in which the pyridine groups can adopt exposure and bridging modes, respectively. (2) the differently oriented N-donor in these isomers will result in different topological structures. In fact, the differently oriented N-donor in these isomers can be attributed to good conformation freedom, which is similar to those built from flexible aliphatic dicarboxylates . In addition, it is obvious that the presence of PDC encourages great variety of resulting complexes. Pyridine groups in 1 and 2 may have different steric hindrance, which can have effect on the coordination modes of carboxylate groups. In fact, the structural diversity is attributed to both positional isomeric effect of tetrahedral linkers and the steric hindrance of PDC used in the self-assembly process.

<ce:section-title>Thermal analyses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was performed in a N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere on polycrystalline samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and the results are shown in . The TG curve of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows the first weight loss of 5.32% (calcd: 6.1%) in the temperature range of 25–131.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which indicates the loss of lattice molecules per formula unit. The framework retains until 356.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and then starts to decompose, with an accompanying loss of organic linkers. For <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the weight loss are attributed to the gradual release of the surface and included water molecules is observed in the range of 25–163.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (obsd: 16.7% and calcd: 3.6%), the framework retains in the temperature range of 163.1–523.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and then decomposes. To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, PXRD experiments were carried out for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The peak positions of the experimental and simulated XRPD patterns are in agreement with each other (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:bold>)</ce:bold>, which shows that the synthesized bulk materials and the measured single crystals are the same.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal analyses

Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was performed in a N2 atmosphere on polycrystalline samples of 1 and 2 and the results are shown in . The TG curve of 1 shows the first weight loss of 5.32% (calcd: 6.1%) in the temperature range of 25-131.3°C, which indicates the loss of lattice molecules per formula unit. The framework retains until 356.4°C, and then starts to decompose, with an accompanying loss of organic linkers. For 2, the weight loss are attributed to the gradual release of the surface and included water molecules is observed in the range of 25-163.1°C (obsd: 16.7% and calcd: 3.6%), the framework retains in the temperature range of 163.1-523.1°C, and then decomposes. To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, PXRD experiments were carried out for 1 and 2. The peak positions of the experimental and simulated XRPD patterns are in agreement with each other (   ), which shows that the synthesized bulk materials and the measured single crystals are the same.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Photoluminescence property</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">In view of the luminescent properties of <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal complexes, Accordingly, the emission spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were measured in the solid state at room temperature (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). When excitated at 390<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits one strong emission maximum at 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. In contrast, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows an weak fluorescent emission peak at 650<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm with an excitation length of 466<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. No obvious photoluminescence was observed for the free L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>, L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and PDC linkers under the same experiment conditions. Thus, the photoluminescence in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be assigned to the emission of ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT). In particular, [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] cores in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can make contributions to luminescent properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence property

In view of the luminescent properties of d 10 metal complexes, Accordingly, the emission spectra of 1 and 2 were measured in the solid state at room temperature (see  ). When excitated at 390nm, 1 exhibits one strong emission maximum at 450nm. In contrast, 2 shows an weak fluorescent emission peak at 650nm with an excitation length of 466nm. No obvious photoluminescence was observed for the free L1, L2 and PDC linkers under the same experiment conditions. Thus, the photoluminescence in 1 can be assigned to the emission of ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT). In particular, [Zn4(PDC)4] cores in 1 can make contributions to luminescent properties.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Two coordination polymers have been successfully isolated under hydrothermal conditions by reactions of L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> or L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and Zn(II) salt, together with auxiliary linkers PDC. Our present discovery indicates that differently oriented N-atoms in the tetrahedral isomers play a significant role in assembly of their final topologies and luminescence-tuning. The successful synthesis of these complexes will provide a new means of luminescence-tuning through the selection of suitable organic building blocks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Two coordination polymers have been successfully isolated under hydrothermal conditions by reactions of L1 or L2 and Zn(II) salt, together with auxiliary linkers PDC. Our present discovery indicates that differently oriented N-atoms in the tetrahedral isomers play a significant role in assembly of their final topologies and luminescence-tuning. The successful synthesis of these complexes will provide a new means of luminescence-tuning through the selection of suitable organic building blocks.

synthesis

Synthesis of the complex 1 

Colorless crystals of 1 were grown from solvothermal reactions of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.3448g, 0.2mmol), L1 (0.0444g, 0.1mmol) and PDC (0.0167g, 0.1mmol) in the mixed solvents of DMF and H2O (v/v=3:3) in a 25mL acid-digestion bomb at 90°C for 3d. The product was washed with water and dried under vacuum. Complex 1 was isolated as a single-phase product (yield: 45.3% based on L1). Anal. Calc. for C53H54N8O25Zn4: C 43.5, H 3.7, N 7.7. Found: C 43.4, H 3.5, N 7.8. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3436.44s, 1414.27s, 1511.31s, 1442.32s, 1365.08s, 1302.85s, 1212.80s, 1062.56s, 1032.92s, 916.60s, 853.05w, 769.16w, 737.90w, 691.71w, 538.54w.

Synthesis of complex 2 

Colorless crystals of 2 were grown from solvothermal reactions of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.3448g, 0.2mmol), L2 (0.0444g, 0.1mmol) and PDC (0.0167g, 0.1mmol) in the mixed solvents of DMF and H2O (v/v=1:5) in a 25mL acid-digestion bomb at 90°C for 3d. The product was washed with water and dried under vacuum. Complex 2 was isolated as a single-phase product (yield: 36.5% based on L2). Anal. Calc. for C64H60N10O19Zn2: C, 54.7, H, 4.3 N, 9.9. Found: C, 54.8, H, 4.4, N, 10.1. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3461.29s, 1641.95s, 1574.08s, 1491.19s 1430.40s, 1369.39s, 1271.11m, 1194.28m, 1105.14m,1005.79m, 907.52w, 807.13w, 770.03w, 728.79w, 700.82w, 671.63w, 635.74w.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Descriptions of crystal structures

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction shows that the complex 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal space group I4(1)/a and the asymmetric unit consists of one Zn(II) ion, one forth of L1, one PDC and five water molecules. Each Zn atom is six-coordinated in a highly distorted octahedral geometry by four oxygen atoms from two distinct PDC, two nitrogen atoms from one L1 and one PDC, The bond lengths are 2.130(2)-2.2393(19)Å for Zn-O, 2.009(2)Å for Zn-N, respectively, and the corresponding bond angles around the Zn atom are in the range of 97.94(9)-152.84(8)°. As shown in  a, the secondary building unit (SBU) of 1 contains a distorted tetrahedral [Zn4(PDC)4] core, in which four ZnII atoms are linked by O-donors from carboxylate groups of PDC with a Zn⋯Zn distance of. 5.055Å. Each tetrahedral linker L1 with the quaternary carbon atom coordinates via its N donor atoms to four [Zn4(PDC)4] cores, resulting in the formation of a 3D framework (b). Better insight into the framework of 1 can be achieved by topology analysis. The tetrahedral linker L1 and [Zn4(PDC)4] core are both viewed as 4-connected nodes, and then the whole networks of 1 can be reduced into a 2-fold interpenetrated sphalerite (ZnS) structure (c). In addition, according to Cheetham's classification, the structure of 1 falls in 3-D network with M-L-M=0 and inorganic connectivity=3 (I3O0) . Two identical 3-D frameworks interpenetrate each other to fill part of free space in 1, leaving relatively large space for the inclusion of water guest molecules. Calculations using PLATON based on the crystal structure show that the total solvent-accessible volume comprises 40.6% of the crystal volume. Steric hindrance effect of pyridine groups in [Zn4(PDC)4] cores could prevent interpenetration, which are more than that of halide groups in Cu4X4 clusters .

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2(1)/n. In the asymmetry unit of 2, there are one Zn atom, one chelating ligand PDC, one L2 ligand and three water guest molecules. Each Zn ion is in a highly distorted octahedral geometry, coordinated by two O-donors from one PDC, four N-donors from three L2 and one PDC. The Zn-O bond distances vary in the range of 2.159(2)-2.197(3)Å, and the Zn-N bond distances vary in the range of 2.028(3)-2.224(3)Å, which are all similar to those found in other Zn(II) compounds  and the corresponding bond angles around the Zn atom are in the range of 75.96(12)-175.78(12)°. Two Zn(II) ions are bridged by the two N-donors from each L2 linker, forming a four-membered [Zn2(L)2] ring, whose internal dimensions is 10.005×9.837Å2 ( a). Each Zn(II) ions [Zn2(L)2] ring is linked by one of the other two N-donors of each L2 linker to generate a two-dimensional (2D) layer structure. Meanwhile, each layer interacts with neighboring layers via hydrogen-bond between the water guest molecules and PDC, further extending the 2D layers into a 3D supramolecular framework (b). To further understand the structure of 2, a topological analysis of the network has been performed using Topos by considering both the metal and L2 as topological nodes. Each tetrahedral linker L2 is 3-connected, and then each Zn ion becomes a 2-connected node. Therefore 2 can be reduced into a (2,3)-connected net with 4.8(2) (c). According to Cheetham's classification, the structure of 2 also belong to 3-D network with M-L-M=0 and inorganic connectivity=3 (I3O0) .

Thermal analyses

Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was performed in a N2 atmosphere on polycrystalline samples of 1 and 2 and the results are shown in . The TG curve of 1 shows the first weight loss of 5.32% (calcd: 6.1%) in the temperature range of 25-131.3°C, which indicates the loss of lattice molecules per formula unit. The framework retains until 356.4°C, and then starts to decompose, with an accompanying loss of organic linkers. For 2, the weight loss are attributed to the gradual release of the surface and included water molecules is observed in the range of 25-163.1°C (obsd: 16.7% and calcd: 3.6%), the framework retains in the temperature range of 163.1-523.1°C, and then decomposes. To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, PXRD experiments were carried out for 1 and 2. The peak positions of the experimental and simulated XRPD patterns are in agreement with each other (   ), which shows that the synthesized bulk materials and the measured single crystals are the same.

Photoluminescence property

In view of the luminescent properties of d 10 metal complexes, Accordingly, the emission spectra of 1 and 2 were measured in the solid state at room temperature (see  ). When excitated at 390nm, 1 exhibits one strong emission maximum at 450nm. In contrast, 2 shows an weak fluorescent emission peak at 650nm with an excitation length of 466nm. No obvious photoluminescence was observed for the free L1, L2 and PDC linkers under the same experiment conditions. Thus, the photoluminescence in 1 can be assigned to the emission of ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT). In particular, [Zn4(PDC)4] cores in 1 can make contributions to luminescent properties.

<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">(a) Coordination environment of [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] cores and L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>. Ball-and-stick (b) and topology (c) representations of the two-interpenetrated diamondoid network (b and c) of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Both [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] and L1 in (b) and (c) are represented as 4-connected nodes. The H atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) Coordination environment of [Zn4(PDC)4] cores and L1. Ball-and-stick (b) and topology (c) representations of the two-interpenetrated diamondoid network (b and c) of complex 1. Both [Zn4(PDC)4] and L1 in (b) and (c) are represented as 4-connected nodes. The H atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity.

L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in (b) and (c) are represented as 3-connected nodes. The H atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
